title: 108_hr3546
content: The Act titled "Meat and Poultry Products Traceability and Safety Act of 2003" mandates traceability of livestock, meat, and meat products under the Federal Meat Inspection Act. The Meat and Poultry Products Traceability and Safety Act of 2003 defines traceability as the ability to track the history, use, and location of livestock and meat products. It requires cattle, sheep, swine, goats, horses, and other animals intended for human consumption to be identified for traceability purposes when shipped across state lines. This includes tracing each animal to its previous locations before slaughter and tracking carcasses and meat products forward. The Secretary will establish a traceability system for all stages of meat production, processing, and distribution. Entry into slaughtering establishments may be prohibited for animals not properly identified. Records must be maintained for identified livestock. The Secretary requires accurate records on livestock purchase, sale, and identification. Access to business premises must be granted for record inspection. Records must be maintained as prescribed by the Secretary. Falsifying information to others is prohibited. No person shall falsify information about premises where livestock are held or alter records without authorization from the Secretary. The Poultry Products Inspection Act is also amended to include regulations on poultry. SEC. 23A. TRACEABILITY OF POULTRY AND POULTRY PRODUCTS. The term "traceability" in this section refers to tracking the history, use, and location of poultry and poultry products. Poultry for human consumption and products shipped across state lines must be identifiable for tracing purposes. The Secretary will establish a traceability system for all stages of production and distribution. The Secretary may prohibit or restrict entry of poultry not identified as prescribed, and require accurate record-keeping of purchase, sale, and identification of poultry by individuals, firms, and corporations involved in the production and distribution of poultry products. The Secretary may prohibit or restrict entry of poultry not identified as prescribed and require accurate record-keeping of purchase, sale, and identification of poultry by individuals, firms, and corporations. A duly authorized representative of the Secretary can access each place of business to examine and copy records. Persons, firms, and corporations must maintain records for the duration specified by the Secretary. It is prohibited to falsify information or alter/destroy records without authorization. The Secretary may prohibit entry of poultry without proper identification and require accurate record-keeping. It is prohibited to alter or destroy records without authorization.
